extracted_data.question_text: What is the name and definition of the software business model presented in the article?
extracted_data.extracted_value: Software-as-a-Service (SaaS). The National Institute of Standards and Technology (NIST) defines SaaS as the capability provided to the consumer of using the provider's applications running on a cloud infrastructure where the applications are accessible from various client devices and interfaces and the consumer generally does not manage or control the infrastructure.
extracted_data.source_citation: Page 1, lines 54-59: 'The National Institute of Standards and Technology (NIST) defines SaaS as the capability provided to the consumer of using the provider's applications running on a cloud infrastructure where the applications are accessible from various client devices and interfaces and the consumer generally does not manage or control the infrastructure (Mell & Grance, 2011).'

cloud services
cloud-based services

extracted_data.question_text: What is the main vertical segment or industry where the software business model presented in the article is applied?
extracted_data.extracted_value: Multiple industries including: music streaming (Apple Music, Spotify, Netflix), hotel management (ZJ Technology), customer service automation (ServiceNow), supply chain analytics (Noodle.ai), CRM (Salesforce.com), cloud computing, enterprise applications

extracted_data.question_text: Which Business Model Canvas elements are detailed in the article about the software business model?
extracted_value: Value Proposition: Software applications delivered via Internet with multitenancy, no geographical constraint, ease of monitoring user behavior, analytics and improvements based on user-generated data, scalability and rapid elasticity
Customer Segment: Businesses and consumers, heterogeneous clients, IT executives, enterprise customers, individual users
Channels: Internet delivery, platforms, social networks, user devices, direct sales, demos, free trials
Revenue Streams: Subscription fees, usage-based pricing, two-part tariff, three-part tariff, transaction fees, advertising
Key Resources: Cloud infrastructure (private, public, hybrid), data centers, computing capacity, user-generated data
Key Activities: Service delivery, capacity management, quality of service management, security and privacy protection, usage analytics, customer support
Key Partnerships: Cloud computing providers (AWS, Azure), platform partnerships (Salesforce, SAP), third-party developers
Cost Structure: Infrastructure costs, service costs, capacity costs, usage costs, variable costs
extracted_data.source_citation: Page 2, lines 110-117: 'Johnson et al. (2008) define a business model as interlocking elements that create and deliver value together: customer value proposition, profit formula, key resources, and key processes' | Page 1-2, lines 64-91: unique features and business characteristics include 'Internet delivery', 'multitenancy', 'variety of pricing options', 'integration with platforms', 'analytics and improvements based on user-generated data', 'scalability, rapid elasticity' | Page 2, lines 118-124 and Figure 2: 'pricing and operations characterize the provider's profit formula (revenue and cost) by utilizing key resources and implementing key processes'

extracted_data.question_text: Which actors participate in the ecosystem of the software business model presented in the article and how do they interact?
extracted_value: SaaS Providers | Deliver applications to end users | Acquire infrastructure from cloud providers, integrate with platforms, compete with other SaaS providers
Cloud Infrastructure Providers (AWS, Azure, Google Cloud) | Provide computing resources, storage, infrastructure | Sell services to SaaS providers, compete on pricing and quality
Platform Operators (Salesforce, SAP) | Host third-party applications | Enable SaaS providers to operate on their platform, may compete with SaaS providers
End Users/Customers | Consume SaaS applications | Pay subscription fees, generate data, provide feedback
Third-party Developers | Create complementary applications | Integrate with platforms and SaaS providers
Competitors (OTS software providers) | Offer alternative solutions | Compete with SaaS providers for market share
extracted_data.source_citation: Page 11, lines 1076-1079: 'Anselmi et al. (2017) model a marketplace with users purchasing services from SaaS providers, which in turn acquire computing resources from infrastructure providers such as AWS' | Page 15, lines 1501-1503: 'The Salesforce platform differentiated from incumbents such as Oracle by encouraging developers to create third-party apps on the platform' | Page 4, lines 272-279: 'For many software markets, incumbents remain providers of off-the-shelf (OTS) software that is often customized for heterogeneous clients, whereas SaaS is not' and 'Ma and Seidmann (2015) examine competition between customized commercial OTS software and uncustomized SaaS'

No geographical constraint and ease of access

Integration with platforms and third-party APIs
Analytics capabilities based on user-generated data
Scalability and rapid elasticity
Competitive pricing advantages
Creating competitive advantages through revamping pricing schemes
extracted_data.source_citation: Page 3, lines 240-243: 'Benlian and Hess (2011) analyze a survey of 349 German IT executives and find that cost advantages affect perceptions of SaaS opportunities heavily' | Page 1, lines 66-79: unique features include 'no geographical constraint', 'ease of monitoring user behavior', 'ease of deployment and updates', 'integration with third-party application programming interface (API)', 'scalability, rapid elasticity' | Page 3, lines 223-225: 'This suggests that revamping SaaS pricing schemes can create competitive advantages and lead to new research opportunities'

extracted_data.question_text: What factors contribute to the success of the software business model as described in the article?
extracted_value: Customer success and satisfaction → rabid fan base and customer referrals
Outstanding customer service and cost reimbursement → strengthened commitments and reduced churn
Quality improvements and continuous updates → customer retention
High-quality usage and user engagement → increased renewals and willingness-to-pay
Network effects and user-generated data → more value and better product
Appropriate capacity management and QoS → reduced downtime and improved performance
Security and privacy protection → user adoption and trust
Recommendation systems → reduced churn and increased retention (Netflix saves $1 billion annually)
extracted_data.source_citation: Page 4, lines 261-264: 'We've been successful because we have successful customers, a rabid fan base. These guys tell their friends, these guys take us with them to their next gig' | Page 4, lines 301-304: 'a provider could strengthen such commitments by outstanding customer service and cost reimbursement' | Page 17, lines 1678-1680: 'Netﬂix's recommendation system saves the company $1 billion annually through reduced churn' | Page 12, lines 1176-1178: 'proactive customer education may increase perceived usefulness, and thus increase usage and reduce churning'

Internet connectivity → Software delivery and access
Computing capacity and resources → Meeting customer demand
Data centers and infrastructure → Hosting applications
Security and privacy measures → Customer trust and compliance
Integration capabilities → Platform and third-party connectivity
Customer data management systems → Analytics and personalization
extracted_data.source_citation: Page 1, lines 54-59: 'SaaS as the capability provided to the consumer of using the provider's applications running on a cloud infrastructure where the applications are accessible from various client devices and interfaces' | Page 10, lines 902-912: 'The demand for capacity is satisfied by three different types of clouds: (i) private cloud, (ii) public cloud, and (iii) hybrid cloud' | Page 2, lines 66-72: 'those derived from Internet delivery' and 'those derived from multitenancy'

extracted_data.question_text: What restrictions or incompatibilities are mentioned in the article about the software business model?
extracted_value: Multitenancy architecture → Limited user control on the application and security/privacy concerns
Lack-of-fit or unfit disutility → SaaS is not customized for heterogeneous clients unlike OTS software
Capacity constraints → Service quality degradation and customer utility impairment
Security enhancements → Performance penalty and increased processing time
Compliance challenges → Per-user pricing enforcement difficulties
Integration requirements → Customer business processes and IT systems compatibility issues
extracted_data.source_citation: Page 1-2, lines 77-79: 'multitenancy—security and privacy concerns, ease of deployment and updates, limited user control on the application, and the possible outsourcing of infrastructure' | Page 4, lines 267-271: 'incumbents remain providers of off-the-shelf (OTS) software that is often customized for heterogeneous clients, whereas SaaS is not, meaning that an unfit disutility is attributed to SaaS' | Page 9, lines 928-933: 'When capacity addition is not instantaneous, demand (q) may overwhelm capacity and thus impair customer utility' | Page 14, lines 1333-1340: 'many security enhancements (extra verification steps, etc.) are a hassle for customers and incur additional computing tasks (network communication, encryption/decryption, etc.) that slow down the processing of customer requests. For example, AES 256-bit encryption consumes approximately 40% more in computing resources than AES 128-bit encryption does' | Page 8, lines 768-770: 'SaaS services must often integrate the customers' business processes and information technology (IT) systems, so many problems may appear and bring lack-of-fit costs'

extracted_data.question_text: What challenges are identified in implementing the software business model as presented in the article?
extracted_value: Security and privacy issues could impact all users (multitenancy vulnerability)
Challenging customization despite scalability
Managing heterogeneous user concerns on security and privacy
Capacity management under demand fluctuations
Service quality maintenance and SLA compliance
Customer churn and retention
Competition and market entry barriers
Lack-of-fit costs and customer integration challenges
Privacy compliance issues and data collection practices disclosure
Balancing functionality with security enhancements
extracted_data.source_citation: Page 2, lines 88-91: 'scalability, rapid elasticity, but challenging customization; and service quality, security, and privacy issues could impact all users' | Page 1, lines 48-53: 'what pricing and operational policies should a SaaS provider adopt under heterogeneous user concerns on security and privacy? Why would SaaS usage patterns influence pricing and quality decisions?' | Page 4, lines 297-299: 'Xiao et al. (2020) define SaaS churn as premature termination of the use of the current SaaS system and replacement of it with an alternative' | Page 13, lines 1251-1253: 'media coverage and research (e.g., Zimmeck et al., 2019) show that many apps exhibit potential privacy compliance issues such as not disclosing certain data collection practices'

extracted_data.question_text: What practices are used to mitigate challenges of the software business model as described in the article?
extracted_value: Outstanding customer service and cost reimbursement → Strengthened commitment and reduced churn → Better customer retention
Free trials and demos → Reduced uncertainties in cost savings and quality → Facilitated purchase and migration
LAER model (Land, Adopt, Expand, Renew) → Progressive customer adoption → Market penetration and expansion
Hybrid cloud infrastructure → Managing demand uncertainty → Balanced cost and performance
SLA (service-level agreement) → Guaranteed service levels → Customer trust and compliance
Proactive customer education → Increased perceived usefulness → Increased usage and reduced churning
Security enhancements and encryption → Mitigated security vulnerabilities → User trust and adoption
Usage analytics and recommendation systems → Improved user engagement → Reduced churn (Netflix saves $1 billion annually)

extracted_data.question_text: What is the temporal period and maturity of the software business model as presented in the article?
extracted_data.extracted_value: Observed period: 2011-2021 (literature review), with historical examples from 2003 onwards. Maturity status: Consolidated and growing. The model has experienced a decade of explosive growth with continued expansion predicted.
extracted_data.source_citation: Page 1, lines 16-18: 'Software-as-a-service (SaaS) applications have experienced a decade of explosive growth' | Page 1-2, lines 94-100: 'we have conducted a literature search in leading operations management and information systems journals between January 2011 and August 2021 and found 31 relevant papers' and 'It can be seen that the number of SaaS papers increased gradually in the last decade' | Page 17, lines 1588-1590: 'In the fast-changing industry of SaaS' | Page 3, lines 210-217: 'Since 2003, Apple Inc. has operated an iTunes Store' and 'on June 30, 2015, Apple Inc. launched the Apple Music streaming service'

extracted_data.question_text: What is the type of evidence presented in the article about the software business model?
extracted_data.extracted_value: Literature review. The article conducts a systematic review of 31 papers from leading operations management and information systems journals, with industry examples and secondary data analysis.
extracted_data.source_citation: Page 1, lines 22-35: 'In this paper, we attempt to fill this important gap. We propose a framework of recent business research on SaaS in light of wide adoption of the SaaS business model. This framework broadly classifies SaaS research into two basic themes. For each theme, we review past work that has been instrumental in setting the direction of this line of research and discuss how emerging research opportunities can be addressed' | Page 1-2, lines 93-97: 'To identify relevant themes in SaaS research, we have conducted a literature search in leading operations management and information systems journals between January 2011 and August 2021 and found 31 relevant papers listed in Table EC.7'

Netflix → Example of subscription pricing, recommendation systems, churn reduction, and network effects
ServiceNow → Example of customer service automation SaaS, hybrid cloud infrastructure, and operational excellence

Adobe Systems Inc. / Adobe Creative Cloud → Transformation from OTS to SaaS, bundling strategy
Zoom → Security and privacy challenges during rapid growth
Noodle.ai → AI-as-a-service for supply chain management, customer support practices
ZJ Technology → Hotel management SaaS with multitenant architecture
NetEase Cloud Music (NCM) → Music streaming with social features and user engagement
Spotify → Music streaming with network effects
Amazon Web Services (AWS) / Amazon EC2 → Cloud infrastructure provider, spot pricing
Dropbox → Cloud storage and platform integration
Box Inc. → Cloud storage bundled with enterprise applications
Twilio → Multiple pricing options (pay-per-use and subscription)
Zendesk → Demos and sales approach
Facebook → Privacy challenges and third-party app hosting
Google / Google Cloud / Google Trends → Cloud services and analytics
Stripe → Developer-friendly API for online payments
Braintree → Online payments with transparency and data portability
Prophet → Supply chain planning SaaS with dynamic pricing
Tableau → Integration with Salesforce platform
SAP → Platform integration partner
extracted_data.source_citation: Multiple citations throughout the article including: Page 3, lines 210-220 (Apple Music/iTunes) | Page 12, lines 1150-1159 (Netflix) | Page 9, lines 866-887 (ServiceNow) | Page 15, lines 1497-1510 (Salesforce.com) | Page 4, lines 288-291 (Adobe) | Page 13-14, lines 1308-1332 (Zoom) | Page 8, lines 745-760 (Noodle.ai) | Page 2, lines 169-176 (ZJ Technology) | Page 15, lines 1406-1418 (NetEase Cloud Music)

extracted_data.question_text: Are there variations or subtypes of the software business model described in the article?
extracted_value: Subscription-based SaaS → Fixed monthly/yearly fee for unlimited access
Usage-based SaaS → Pay-per-use, metered pricing based on consumption (transactions, storage, computing)
Freemium SaaS → Free basic service with paid premium features
Tiered/Plans SaaS → Multiple service levels with different features and pricing
Platform-based SaaS → Hosting third-party applications and developer ecosystems
AI-as-a-Service → Machine learning and analytics services (Noodle.ai example)
Hybrid model → Combining subscription with usage-based components
extracted_data.source_citation: Page 3, lines 309-324: 'subscription pricing (a.k.a., flat-fee), two-part tariff (2PT), and three-part tariff (3PT) are ubiquitous choices' and 'tiered (nonlinear) pricing and pay-per-use pricing' | Page 7, lines 674-676: '38% of SaaS companies adopt pricing plans based on usage (transactions, storage, computing, servers)' | Page 17, lines 1667-1674: 'Despite the attractiveness of freemium' and 'tiered pricing combines tariff and bundling' | Page 8, lines 745-746: 'Noodle.ai offers AI-as-a-service' | Page 15, lines 1497-1503: 'Salesforce.com transformed itself into a platform of enterprise business applications'

extracted_data.question_text: What future trends or evolutions are mentioned in the article about the software business model?
extracted_value: Embracing new technologies: Integration of big data, artificial intelligence, IoT, edge computing, 5G, and blockchain into SaaS management
Evolving business models: Transformation toward cloud-based services, organizational changes, platform-based ecosystems
Finer understanding of customers: Advanced recommendation systems, consumer behavior analysis, user learning and decision capacity
Integration with offline businesses: Autonomous vehicles, cloud manufacturing, on-demand service platforms
Better social responsibility: Sustainability efforts, carbon footprint quantification, public health applications, antitrust considerations
Dynamic pricing adoption: Moving from static to dynamic pricing based on market and cost conditions
Enhanced security and privacy: Continued focus on data protection, compliance with regulations (GDPR, COPPA, CalOPPA)
extracted_data.source_citation: Page 17, Section 4, lines 1588-1724: 'FUTURE ROADMAP FOR SAAS' section describes multiple trends including: 'Embracing new technologies' (lines 1596-1615): 'pressing need to embed big data and artificial intelligence', 'IoT and edge computing', '5G', 'blockchain'; 'Evolving business models' (lines 1616-1675): 'transformation toward cloud-based services may prompt an organizational overhaul', 'Digital platforms could enable value-creating interactions'; 'Finer understanding of customers' (lines 1676-1690); 'Integrating with offline businesses' (lines 1691-1706); 'Better social responsibility' (lines 1707-1724): 'SaaS can be used to quantify carbon footprints', 'SaaS tools have been deployed to assist decision making'
